root.pub-comments: This tree is reproduced in Köhler's chapter “Geschichte und Probleme der Gliederung der Sprachen Afrikas” in Baumann's 1975 book “Die Völker Afrikas und ihre traditionellen Kulturen”. The tree was produced originally in 1952, which Köhler presents as an early hypothesis for the relationships of Gur languages. Throughout the rest of this section of his chapter within the volume, Köhler expands upon this hypothesis and those of others. Please consult the original source for a detailed historical analysis of the linguistic classification of Gur languages. Original language: German [deu].
root.publications: Köhler, Oswin. 1975. Geschichte und Probleme der Gliederung der Sprachen Afrikas. In Hermann Baumann (ed.), Die Völker Afrikas und ihre traditionellen Kulturen, 137-373. Wiesbaden: Franz Steiner Verlag GmbH.

child.pub-comments:
Köhler uses names that are very uncommon and are difficult to identify for many of the languages in his Bobo group. Nyenyege has been identified as an ethnonym for speakers of the Buamu language [box], but Köhler's other three languages have not been able to be further specified within his subgrouping. The three remaining languages of the Bwa (Bobo) subgroup, according to the Ethnologue analysis, must correspond to the three remaining languages mentioned in the Köhler article, but they cannot be individually assigned with a high degree of certainty.
Concurrently, Köhler breaks with his systematic formatting with this group. As written in the source material, it is unclear if the constituent languages of this subgroup, as presented here, are, in fact, meant to correspond to languages within a subgroup, dialects of a particular language (Bobo), or alternate names for the entire group.

child.pub-comments:
Köhler writes that this group “contains names from stems etc. according to Delafosse 1904, 1908/09, Tauxier 1921, and Welmers 1950I-II.” He does not go into further detail, nor document the internal structure of the group.
(“Senufo-Gruppe. Enthält Namen von Stämmen usw. Nach Delafosse 1904, 1908/09, Tauxier 1921 und Welmers 1950I-II.”)
(Köhler 1975: 187)
